intro: Galium gilliesii subsp. telanthos, commonly known as the Sierra tephrosia, is a herbaceous perennial native to the western United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and opposite, lanceolate leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers in clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and streambanks. Its botanical features make it an important component of its native ecosystem.
